articles.title: RSF massacres left Sudanese city ‘a slaughterhouse’, satellite images show
articles.trailText: Up to 150,000 residents of El Fasher are missing since North Darfur capital fell to paramilitary Rapid Support Forces
articles.summary: In El Fasher, North Darfur, six weeks after RSF seized the city, satellite imagery reveals dozens of corpse piles and newly dug mass burial and incineration pits. British MPs were briefed on at least 60,000 killed; up to 150,000 residents remain unaccounted for. With markets overgrown, livestock gone and UN investigators barred, experts warn of famine and describe the city as a “slaughterhouse.” Aid convoys await RSF security guarantees. Human rights groups deem El Fasher the worst atrocity of Sudan’s civil war and call for war crimes probes, including against prior RSF attacks on displaced camps.

articles.title: How three Uyghur brothers fled China – to spend 12 years in an Indian prison
articles.trailText: Arrested in 2013 on India’s Himalayan border after fleeing Beijing’s ‘genocide’ against Muslims in Xinjiang, the siblings have been imprisoned indefinitely ever since
articles.summary: Three Uyghur brothers – Adil (23), Abdul Khaliq (22) and Salamu (20) – fled state-sponsored ‘re-education’ camps and persecution in Xinjiang in June 2013, reached Ladakh and were arrested by the Indian army for illegal entry. After an 18-month sentence they should have been freed in 2015, but under the Modi government authorities have repeatedly invoked the Public Safety Act to detain them indefinitely. Now held in Haryana’s Karnal prison under harsh conditions, with health problems and no visa or asylum status, they await a legal resolution as their lawyer fights pro bono for asylum or release.

articles.title: ‘One bite and he was hooked’: from Kenya to Nepal, how parents are battling ultra-processed foods
articles.trailText: Five families around the world share their struggles to keep their children away from UPFs
articles.summary: Global review in The Lancet warns ultra-processed foods (UPFs) now displace fresh diets across continents, driving rises in obesity and non-communicable diseases. Unicef reports more children worldwide are obese than underweight. Five families in Nepal, St Vincent & the Grenadines, Uganda, India and Kenya share struggles: from Nepal school canteens serving sugary juices (69% of infants eat UPFs) to Caribbean fast-food proliferation post-hurricane as produce vanishes; Kampala malls’ KFC outlets lure kids; Indian parents battle refined-sugar snacks and counterfeit paneer; and Kenyan children stealthily smuggle instant noodles. They urge stricter marketing controls and healthier school environments.

articles.title: Uganda stops granting refugee status for Eritreans, Somalis and Ethiopians
articles.trailText: Government once seen as progressive on migration says aid cuts to blame for excluding countries ‘not experiencing war’
articles.summary: Uganda’s refugee minister Hillary Onek has barred Eritreans, Somalis and Ethiopians from new asylum or refugee status, blaming severe UNHCR aid cuts—from $240m to under $100m annually and only $18m this year—while hosting nearly 2m refugees, including 56,000+ Eritreans, 50,000 Somalis and 16,000 Ethiopians. Amid global aid declines by the US and UK, the WFP received 2,544 tonnes of rice ($2.9m) from South Korea. Uganda’s $968m 2025 refugee response plan is just 25% funded, prompting fears services will collapse and force returns to conflict or camps, reversing its former liberal policy.

articles.title: Whistleblower accuses Foreign Office of ‘censoring’ warning of Sudan genocide
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Analyst claims UK officials deleted alert to threat of genocidal violence by paramilitaries to protect UAE
articles.summary: An anonymous FCDO risk analyst alleges UK officials removed warnings of potential genocide in Darfur from an April 2023 report to shield the UAE, accused of arming the brutal Rapid Support Forces. The analyst and a former atrocity-prevention officer claim this mirrors earlier suppression of DRC human-rights alerts, sacrificing atrocity prevention for political ties. After RSF massacres in El Geneina and El Fasher killed thousands, the UK still refuses to label events genocide without judicial ruling. Critics warn this censorship enabled ongoing mass atrocities and calls for urgent policy change.

articles.title: How Kenya’s jailhouse lawyer turned a life sentence into a legal career behind bars
articles.trailText: After being incarcerated for murdering her partner, Ruth Kamande studied the legal system to understand her own case. Now she is fighting to reform Kenya’s laws
articles.summary: Ruth Kamande, jailed in Kenya’s Lang’ata maximum-security prison for the 2015 stabbing of her partner, transformed her life sentence into a legal career. While serving a commuted life term (after her 2018 death penalty was reduced in 2023), the 30-year-old earned a University of London LLB via Justice Defenders programmes, assisted fellow inmates—especially marginalised women lacking representation—and now advocates legal reform (parole, fixed life terms, battered-woman defence). Citing remorse and self-defence claims, Kamande awaits a retrial and leads a prison working group to reshape Kenya’s justice system.

articles.title: No soap, no tents, no food: Rohingya families fight for survival as aid plummets
articles.trailText: In Bangladesh, over a million people in the world’s largest refugee camp depend on aid – and cuts mean new arrivals are not even given shelter
articles.summary: Over 1.1 million Rohingya refugees in Cox’s Bazar live in precarious shelters, with new arrivals since early 2024 denied tents or basic items due to a 63% aid funding gap. Closure of 48 health centres left infants and pregnant women increasingly vulnerable; acute malnutrition cases under five rose 11% year-on-year. Mothers deliver on tattered mattresses by failing generators and borrow funds for treatment. Blocked from work or education, refugees face shrinking rations and deepening dependence on dwindling humanitarian support.

articles.title: Aid cuts have shaken HIV/Aids care to its core – and will mean millions more infections ahead
articles.trailText: Reports highlight devastating impact of slashed funding, especially in parts of Africa, that could lead to 3.3m new HIV infections by 2030
articles.summary: US, UK and European aid cuts have slashed external HIV funding in sub-Saharan Africa by 30–40% since 2023, shuttering clinics in Mozambique, Zimbabwe and Ethiopia and exhausting test kits in the DRC. UNAIDS warns these cuts could drive 3.3m additional infections by 2030 as prevention services—particularly PrEP and community outreach for key populations (MSM, sex workers, transgender people, prisoners)—collapse (e.g., Burundi’s PrEP recipients fell 64%). Frontline Aids reports rising AIDS deaths and rising new cases in Kenya and elsewhere. While Nigeria, Uganda, South Africa and Tanzania pledge domestic funding and explore long-acting injectables, experts stress urgent political will is needed to restore prevention, rebuild community-led programmes and protect human rights.

articles.title: Why women kill
articles.trailText: Experience of domestic violence is at the heart of why many women are driven to commit violent crimes
articles.summary: Despite women committing only around 10% of homicides, most who kill a partner act after enduring sustained domestic abuse. Research shows nearly all women on death row worldwide murdered abusers and face punitive, patriarchal justice systems that dismiss trauma, coercive control and mental health impacts. Landmark cases—from the UK’s 2019 coercive control defence to Belize and Kenya rulings—hint at reform, while activists urge UN action to mandate gender-sensitive evidence, self-defence law reform and recognition of abuse as a mitigating factor. Data gaps hinder research, and progress toward fair trials remains painfully slow.

articles.title: How many women are in prison and on death row around the world? – in charts
articles.trailText: While fewer women than men are incarcerated, their numbers are rising faster and most often for non-violent offences
articles.summary: Over 733,000 women and girls—6.8% of the global prison population—are incarcerated worldwide, a nearly 60% rise since 2000 driven by poverty-linked, often non-violent offences (survival crimes, drug trafficking, abortion). The US (174,607), China (145,000+), Brazil (50,441), Russia (39,153) and Thailand (33,057) hold the most female inmates, while El Salvador, Cambodia, Indonesia and Turkey have seen the sharpest per-capita increases. An estimated 500-1,000 women sit on death row for murder and drug crimes in China, Iran, Iraq and Saudi Arabia. Non-custodial measures and the UN’s Bangkok Rules aim to reduce recidivism, address mental illness and limit family separation—1.45 million children have incarcerated mothers.

articles.title: Experts warn of ‘global crisis��� as number of women in prison nears one million
articles.trailText: Number of women incarcerated around the world rising at nearly three times the rate of men, with female prisoners often subjected to sexual violence and forced labour
articles.summary: Global female prison population has surged 57% since 2000, nearing one million and outpacing male growth, experts warn. Women, often jailed for petty offences or drug crimes driven by poverty and discrimination, face sexual violence, forced labour and harsh conditions. Many lack gender-specific healthcare, mental health support and suffer trauma from strip searches and overcrowding. Despite the UN’s Bangkok Rules, accountability is weak. The US and China hold the largest numbers. Campaigners call for non-custodial measures, noting the wider harm to mothers, children and communities.

articles.title: ‘They killed my only son’: the young west African footballers scammed by fake agents
articles.trailText: Cheikh Touré died after being lured abroad in one of a growing number of extortion schemes tricking talented teenagers with dreams of making it big
articles.summary: Eighteen-year-old goalkeeper Cheikh Touré left Dakar expecting trials in Morocco but was abducted, taken to Ghana and held for ransom by fake agents, who demanded 850,000 CFA. His mother raised 650,000 CFA before he stopped responding; his body, bearing fatal wounds, arrived at a Kumasi hospital. Scammers promising European or North African contracts target impoverished West African teens, charging thousands up-front for bogus trials or academies. A 2023 Fifpro survey found 70% of players approached by unscrupulous agents, over half never receiving promised trials. Experts warn these criminal networks exploit families’ hopes, urging stricter vetting of agents.

articles.title: ‘They began taking my friends from school’: the children being recruited by Colombia’s armed groups
articles.trailText: Militias are coercing, bribing and kidnapping young people in remote areas to be fighters, drug sellers, informants or sex slaves
articles.summary: Armed groups in remote Colombian regions such as Norte de Santander are increasingly recruiting children—coercing, bribing and kidnapping youths with promises of money, phones and belonging. Documented cases climbed from dozens in 2021 to over 600 in 2024, likely underestimates. Teenagers like 14-year-old Ana, 15-year-old Juan and 16-year-old Andrea were forced into roles as fighters, drug couriers, informants and sex slaves. Children serve as frontline fighters and human shields; escape attempts are brutally punished. Survivors now live at Bogotá’s Benposta refuge school, receiving education, counselling and hope to rebuild lives as students and pursue dreams of psychologist or footballer careers.

articles.title: How rolling sand dunes are creeping up on last remaining oases on edge of Sahara
articles.trailText: In western Chad, villagers are desperately trying to hold back the sand as the climate crisis wreaks havoc on one of the hottest countries in the world
articles.summary: In Kanem province, western Chad, oases like Kaou—lifelines for over 500 families and 100 farmers—are being overtaken by shifting dunes and extreme heat as temperatures rise twice the global average. Villagers, with SOS Sahel’s aid, built palm-frond barriers and installed solar pumps, growing vegetables and dates. But funding lapsed in early 2024, forcing many young men back to hazardous goldfields. A similar project in Barkadroussou, still running since 2014, sustains 300 farmers and 3,000 residents, highlighting the fragility of desert-adaptation efforts under climate stress.

articles.title: Control of HIV, TB and malaria at risk after global health fund donations fall
articles.trailText: World leaders pledge just over $11bn, short of the $18bn experts say is needed to stay on track to tackle challenges
articles.summary: Donors have pledged only $11.3bn of the $18bn the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, TB and malaria needs for 2026–28, threatening efforts to curb these diseases. Major backers—France, Japan and the European Commission—have yet to confirm pledges, while the US cut its contribution from $6bn to $4.6bn and the UK trimmed its commitment from £1bn to £850m. Advocates warn shortfalls endanger advances in HIV prevention, TB treatment and malaria control. Although some countries (Ireland, India) and private foundations increased support, calls grow for a funding model that protects poorest nations with grants and issues loans to wealthier states.

articles.title: Huge staff cuts at WHO will leave world ‘less healthy and safe’, experts warn
articles.trailText: Health organisation is to lose almost a quarter of its workforce in 2026, reducing its ability to help countries facing disease outbreaks
articles.summary: Facing a $500m salary gap worsened by the US withdrawal and other funding cuts, WHO will eliminate 2,371 posts—nearly 25% of its 9,401-strong workforce—by June 2026. Geneva HQ will lose 805 roles and the Africa office 638 of 2,541 posts. Experts warn slashing disease surveillance, supply chains and emergency response undermines pandemic coordination and support for low-income nations. About half the reductions will occur via attrition and half by position abolition, triggering staff unrest as junior employees accuse senior roles of being shielded. Observers urge the World Health Assembly to clarify WHO’s core mandate and secure sustainable funding to restore global health security.

articles.title: How dead pigs are helping in the search for missing victims of Mexico’s drug wars
articles.trailText: Tens of thousands of families are desperately searching for loved ones ‘disappeared’ by the country’s drug cartels. Now, pigs, drones and AI are being used to find clandestine graves
articles.summary: Tens of thousands of Mexicans have been ‘disappeared’ by drug cartels; Jalisco alone records over 15,000 missing. To protect families from cartel reprisals, the Jalisco Search Commission and volunteer mothers, with Oxford and local universities, bury pig carcasses in 16 plots to map plant growth and simulate human decomposition. They combine electrical resistivity tomography, multispectral drone imaging and AI to pinpoint clandestine graves. Trials have identified 15 indicator plant species and cartel burial patterns—nearly always near sweet acacia or mesquite trees—and quickly uncovered 29 bagged remains in Zapopan. Officials say the innovation accelerates recovery of victims but cannot solve the root causes of Mexico’s drug war.

articles.title: New drug could be a breakthrough in treatment for killer TB, trial suggests
articles.trailText: Sorfequiline shows stronger action than existing treatments against illness that killed 1.23 million last year
articles.summary: With TB causing 10.7 million cases and 1.23 million deaths last year and WHO warning of stalled progress towards ending TB, a phase-2 trial of sorfequiline in 309 patients across South Africa, the Philippines, Georgia, Tanzania and Uganda demonstrated stronger bactericidal activity than current six-month regimens, with a comparable safety profile. Researchers propose a universal, shorter antibiotic regimen that bypasses delays in drug-resistance testing, boosting cure rates and reducing clinic visits. Phase-3 trials are slated for 2026. Observers caution that broad use could risk overtreatment and deter investments in diagnostics and lab capacity.

articles.title: Tanzania’s descent into repression is a stark warning of how fast Africa’s progress can be eroded | Kenneth Mohammed
articles.trailText: When she became president, Samia Suluhu Hassan offered hope. But the country’s sudden democratic decay is more than just a national tragedy
articles.summary: Africa’s economic boom masks a governance crisis across the continent. The Mo Ibrahim Foundation warns of declining scores, coups and insurgencies since 2020. Tanzania under President Samia Suluhu Hassan regressed after initial liberal reforms. October 2025’s election saw key opposition figures barred, internet blackouts and military deployment. Hassan claimed 97.6% of votes amid credible reports of arbitrary arrests, killings and mass graves. The UN cites “hundreds” killed; rights groups estimate up to 3,000 deaths. Activists like Tundu Lissu and Sativa were abducted or disappeared. This repression mirrors autocratic trends in Uganda, Sudan and eastern DRC, prompting calls for UN, AU and SADC investigations.

articles.title: This Nepal village has survived for 1,000 years. Now recurring floods threaten its future
articles.trailText: Til, the remotest of three villages in the Limi valley on the Tibetan border, was already wrestling with a dwindling population but a series of natural disasters has led many to consider where their future should be
articles.summary: Til, a 1,000-year-old Himalayan village at 4,000 m on Nepal’s Tibetan border, is facing existential threats as sudden glacial floods—likely from thawing permafrost—swept away homes, bridges and vital infrastructure in May and July. With no state aid, the Limi Youth Society launched a GoFundMe for tents, solar lights and a temporary bridge, and lobbied at Nepal’s inaugural climate summit. Repeated disasters, youth outmigration and monastery closures now threaten the village’s cultural heritage, prompting demands for lake drainage, infrastructure investment and planned relocation to preserve their traditions.

articles.title: Nestlé accused of ’risking health of babies for profit’ over added sugar in cereals sold in African countries
articles.trailText: Campaigners say the company is contributing to rising rates of childhood obesity, while the firm says it is helping to combat malnutrition
articles.summary: Public Eye’s probe of 94 Cerelac samples from over 20 African countries found added sugar in more than 90%—an average of 6g per serving—contravening WHO guidelines that recommend no added sweeteners for under-3s. Campaigners accuse Nestlé of ‘double standards’ and risking infant health for profit amid rising childhood obesity, while Nestlé defends its formulas as meeting local regulations, combating malnutrition and ensuring palatability. The company highlights recent no-sugar launches in India and plans to roll them out across Africa.

articles.title: UK warned that 15% cut to health fund will force ‘impossible choices’ on Africa
articles.trailText: Advocates fear that other donors will follow Britain’s reduction to the Global Fund for Aids, TB and malaria
articles.summary: The UK has cut its Global Fund pledge for AIDS, TB and malaria by 15%—from £1 bn to £850 m—reducing aid spending from 0.5% to 0.3% of GDP. Campaigners fear other donors will follow, forcing African states to choose between bed nets, diagnostics and new HIV-prevention drugs. Research warns a 20% Global Fund cut could cause 330 000 extra malaria deaths by 2040. Advocates urge PM Keir Starmer to attend the Johannesburg replenishment, increase the pledge and uphold UK leadership in global health.

articles.title: ‘Will it change the weather? Will wildlife cope?’: Europe’s rush to build energy projects in Chile might not be as green as it seems
articles.trailText: The country’s government is upbeat about the economic prospects of the growing number of windfarms, solar parks and industrial complexes but others warn of ‘green colonialism’
articles.summary: European and British firms have announced over 50 green hydrogen and ammonia megaprojects in Chile’s Patagonia and Atacama, backed by EU and UK financing. These developments include vast windfarms, solar parks, desalination plants and pipelines across thousands of sq km. Chile’s government touts clean-energy exports and job creation, but researchers, farmers, fishers and indigenous communities warn of “green colonialism,” ecosystem damage—from salt discharge and turbine noise to bird collisions—and threats to livelihoods and fragile marine coasts. Only one small pilot in Magallanes is operational, with the rest awaiting environmental approval.

articles.title: China and Saudi Arabia among nations receiving climate loans, analysis reveals
articles.trailText: Investigation by Guardian and Carbon Brief finds just a fifth of funds to fight global heating went to poorest 44 countries
articles.summary: Guardian and Carbon Brief analysis of UN and OECD data shows that in 2021–22, wealthier polluters like China, Saudi Arabia and UAE received billions in public climate finance, largely as loans, despite UN commitments. Only 20% of funds reached the 44 least developed countries, often as debt-burdening loans (95% in Bangladesh/Angola). India led with $14bn, China $3bn; Balkans and EU hopefuls took $3.5bn-plus. Advocates warn loan-heavy funding risks debt traps and call for more grants.

articles.title: What exactly is climate finance? Who pays it? And who gets it?
articles.trailText: Richer countries have agreed to give poorer nations hundreds of billions to cut emissions, but details can be hard to find
articles.summary: Richer nations pledged $100bn/yr by 2020 at Copenhagen, later raising it to $300bn/yr by 2035. OECD reports $116bn in 2022; Oxfam counts $95bn with <$35bn in grants. Over 75% of funding is public, split between bilateral, multilateral and mobilised private finance; two-thirds as loans—mostly non-concessional—adding debt pressures. Major donors (US, Japan, Germany, France) fund diverse recipients: the poorest 44 countries, lower- and upper-middle-income states and even petro-states. New UN target of $1.3tn/yr (including $300bn public) relies heavily on opaque private investments. Cop talks will focus on transparency, debt-for-climate swaps and new taxes.

articles.title: Myopic cut in UK aid for global health fund is a huge mistake | Letter
articles.trailText: Letters: Desmond Whyms on the need to build strong health systems and for governments to look beyond short-term savings
articles.summary: Desmond Whyms warns that the UK’s £150 million cut to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria undercuts decades of leadership and jeopardizes the Fund’s record of saving 70 million lives since 2022. He argues that short-term savings sacrifice critical investments in regional vaccine and medicine production, resilient indigenous health systems and proven prevention measures—such as indoor air-quality improvements, which lack targets and budgets in current strategies—undermining future pandemic preparedness and perpetuating dependence on wealthier nations’ aid.

articles.title: ‘Utter hypocrisy’: tobacco firm lobbied against rules in Africa that are law in UK
articles.trailText: British American Tobacco pushed Zambian ministers to drop or delay ad bans, health warnings and restrictions on flavoured products, letter shows
articles.summary: British American Tobacco lobbied Zambian ministers to abandon or delay tobacco ad bans, sponsorship restrictions, flavoured product limits, and large graphic health warnings ahead of a parliamentary bill that would mandate e-cigarette regulation and 75% packaging warnings. A leaked BAT Zambia letter proposes reducing warnings to 30-50%, watering down penalties—from fines tied to turnover to 10 years’ imprisonment—and exempting certain flavours, arguing stricter rules spur illicit trade. Critics, including WHO and local campaigners, label this “utter hypocrisy,” noting UK law already enforces such measures and warning such interference risks 7,000 annual deaths in Zambia.

articles.title: Olympians call on Iran to halt execution of boxing champion
articles.trailText: Sports personalities including Martina Navratilova and the swimmer Sharron Davies sign letter condemning Mohammad Javad Vafaei Sani’s death sentence
articles.summary: Over 20 Olympic medallists and coaches—including Martina Navratilova and Sharron Davies—have signed a letter urging the UN, sports federations and governments to halt Iran’s execution of 30-year-old boxing champion and coach Mohammad Javad Vafaei Sani. Arrested for participating in 2019 protests and accused of supporting the MEK, he has endured torture and solitary confinement. Activists denounce his grossly unfair trial and warn that executing a political athlete undermines sport’s values, free expression and serves as a warning to dissenters.

articles.title: My father, Ken Saro-Wiwa, died fighting for a clean Nigeria. Thirty years on it’s time to stop sucking on the dirty teat of the oil cash cow | Noo Saro-Wiwa
articles.trailText: In 1995, as one of the Ogoni Nine, he was hanged after protesting against Shell’s oil pollution. With education and a move towards renewable energy, we can honour his legacy
articles.summary: Thirty years after Ken Saro-Wiwa’s 1995 hanging as part of the Ogoni Nine for protesting Shell’s environmental destruction, President Tinubu’s 2025 pardon stops short of exoneration. Noo Saro-Wiwa denounces successive administrations’ failure to clear her father’s name, condemns ongoing oil dependence—despite Shell’s 1993 withdrawal, 2008 Bodo spill compensation and sale of onshore leases to a local consortium—and highlights stalled Hyprep clean-up, pipeline sabotage and rising unemployment driving calls to resume drilling. She calls for a sustainable shift toward education, renewable energy and ecotourism, citing a solar plant in Umuolu, Apoi Creek conservation and her Foundation’s plans for non-oil entrepreneurship in Ogoniland.

articles.title: US to demand countries share data on ‘pathogens with epidemic potential’ in return for health aid
articles.trailText: Draft template seen by the Guardian has no reference to countries receiving benefits for sharing information, such as guaranteed access to medicines developed as a result
articles.summary: The US draft bilateral health-aid template, part of its America First Global Health Strategy, conditions five-year assistance for HIV, malaria, TB, polio and lab systems on rapid sharing of specimens and genetic sequences of ‘pathogens with epidemic potential.’ Countries must gradually fund programs themselves and recognise US regulatory approvals, yet the draft omits guarantees for access to resulting vaccines and treatments. Civil society and WHO critics warn this undermines multilateral PABS negotiations, threatens equity, data security and sovereignty, and bypasses WHO-led pandemic preparedness frameworks.

articles.title: ‘Drug trafficking, extortion, kidnapping’: the lawless rush for rare earth minerals in Venezuela
articles.trailText: Guerrilla groups have seized control of mining areas, exploiting Indigenous people and fuelling environmental ruin on the border with Colombia
articles.summary: Amid the global energy shift, guerrilla groups like Colombia’s ELN and FARC dissidents have overtaken tin, coltan and rare earth mining in Venezuela’s Orinoco and Amazon regions, exploiting Indigenous Curripaco and Piaroa communities through extortion, kidnapping and forced labor. Fraudulent export chains mask origins as minerals flow via Colombian ports to China. Armed fronts carve up territory, trafficking drugs and minerals, co-opting local leaders, while rampant deforestation, river contamination and sex trafficking illustrate a lawless boom driven by geopolitics and weak regulation.

articles.title: ‘Politicians actually taking action’: six world mayors defying climate-sceptic populist leaders
articles.trailText: From Sierra Leone to Milan, cities are crafting their own rules and innovations in the face of rising temperatures
articles.summary: At the C40 summit in Rio, six mayors—from Freetown to Milan, Melbourne, Phoenix, Despeñaderos and Fortaleza—are sidestepping national climate-sceptic leaders to advance local climate measures. Freetown’s mayor converts faecal sludge into cooking briquettes and seeks a cable-car system to curb deforestation; Milan’s enforces the EU’s largest low-emission zone and food-waste reduction in schools; Melbourne is lobbying renewable-powered datacentre standards; Phoenix combats record heat with cool pavements and light rail despite lost federal support; Despeñaderos rolls out solar panels and upcycles plastic; Fortaleza has added micro-parks covering 4,100 football pitches.

articles.title: UK rejected atrocity prevention plans for Sudan despite warning of possible genocide
articles.trailText: Exclusive: British government adopted ‘least ambitious’ option months before RSF’s massacres in El Fasher
articles.summary: UK rejected robust atrocity prevention plans for Sudan despite warnings of genocidal ethnic cleansing in El Fasher, choosing its “least ambitious” of four FCDO options amid aid cuts. An internal paper cited resource and staffing constraints, limiting additional funding to £10m via ICRC and partners rather than a comprehensive protection mechanism. After RSF forces seized El Fasher in October 2025, mass killings, rapes and thousands missing exposed the failure of this minimalist approach. An ICAI review condemned cuts that stalled conflict-related sexual violence programmes and delayed women’s protection until 2026. Critics say the decision undermines the UK’s UN penholder role and risks complicity in Darfur’s ongoing genocide despite £120m pledged aid.

articles.title: ‘The chilling effect’: how fear of ‘nudify’ apps and AI deepfakes is keeping Indian women off the internet
articles.trailText: Widespread adoption of artificial intelligence has been accompanied by new ways to harass women online
articles.summary: In India, growing adoption of AI ‘nudify’ apps and deepfake tools has fuelled a surge in online harassment of women, from doctored nude images to extortion. A Rati Foundation and Tattle report finds 10% of helpline cases now involve AI-manipulated content, driving a “chilling effect” that silences women like law graduate Gaatha Sarvaiya. Legal remedies remain slow and platforms’ takedown processes opaque, while content recurs across YouTube, Meta and WhatsApp, deepening fatigue and self-censorship.

articles.title: When 14-year-old Leanne went missing, police labelled her a runaway. Her family say it’s because she is Native American
articles.trailText: Urban cases of missing and murdered Indigenous people in the US are regularly erased or dismissed, say campaigners, with families left to search for loved ones alone
articles.summary: When Leanne Marie Hausberg, a 14-year-old biracial Native American teen, vanished in Brooklyn on 18 March 1999, the NYPD dismissed her as a runaway and misclassified her race until 2010. Campaigners say such erasure of urban missing and murdered Indigenous people is widespread: Native Americans disappear at twice the per capita rate of whites, with 92% of missing Indigenous children cases off-reservation. Families like Leanne’s and that of 21-year-old Jordan Novak bear investigative burdens. Advocates demand accurate race-based data, culturally competent protocols and survivor-led accountability.

articles.title: Forget petty bribes, ‘state capture’ is corruption so deep it is shaping the rules of democracy itself | Kenneth Mohammed
articles.trailText: Beating the dangerous influence of private interests on governments requires independent judges, journalists and a courageous civil society
articles.summary: Youth-led protests across Asia, Africa and Latin America have mobilized against state capture — an entrenched form of corruption where elites rewrite laws to serve private interests, hollowing democracy. From South Africa’s Gupta era and Russia’s oligarchs to Hungary’s judicial purges and dynasties in Kazakhstan, public institutions function as cartels. Transnational capture by lobby groups like AIPAC highlights risks to open democracies. Petitioning independent judiciaries, fearless journalism and mobilized civil society are vital to reclaim governance. Grassroots movements demonstrate that lasting democratic renewal must be forced from below.

articles.title: Child bride faces execution in Iran unless she pays £80,000 in ‘blood money’
articles.trailText: Goli Kouhkan, 25, on death row for seven years for killing her abusive husband, has until December to settle with the victim’s family
articles.summary: Goli Kouhkan, 25, a Baluch former child bride in Iran, has been on death row seven years after being sentenced to qisas for her role in the 2018 killing of her abusive husband. Married at 12, she endured rape and beatings and acted when he attacked their five-year-old son. Illiterate and without legal counsel, she confessed under pressure and received a hanging sentence. Under Iranian law, she can avoid execution by paying 10bn tomans (£80,000) to the victim’s family by December and leaving Gorgan. Human rights groups say her case highlights systemic gender discrimination, legal tolerance of child marriage and the state’s use of executions against women.

articles.title: Aid cuts could set back fragile gains in eliminating neglected tropical diseases | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: In response to an editorial on the uptick in malaria, Prof Heather Ferguson writes that progress against dengue, leprosy, rabies and other conditions could unravel
articles.summary: In a letter responding to a Guardian editorial, Prof Heather Ferguson warns that cuts to USAID and wavering UK aid risk unraveling decades of progress not only against malaria but also neglected tropical diseases (NTDs) such as dengue, leprosy and rabies. Affecting over a billion people, NTDs saw a 900 million case reduction between 1990 and 2021, elimination of at least one disease in 54 countries and near-eradication of guinea worm, thanks to pharmaceutical donations and government support. Ferguson argues modest, sustained funding is essential to preserve these fragile gains amid climate change and avoid reversing hard-won health advances.

articles.title: He told the world what was happening in El Fasher. Then they sought him out. How Sudan lost ‘a true hero of the war’
articles.trailText: For months, Mohamed Khamis Douda shared accounts of what life was like under siege. He was killed when RSF fighters finally took the Darfur city, raising fears activists and civil society figures are being hunted down
articles.summary: Sudanese activist Mohamed Khamis Douda, spokesperson for Zamzam displacement camp in Darfur, chronicled life under RSF siege in El Fasher – from hunger, drone surveillance and makeshift bomb shelters to eating cattle hides when supplies ran out. He reported RSF atrocities, including use of Colombian mercenaries, organized burials, aid and educated media, despite death threats and contact tracing by RSF. When RSF forces overran El Fasher on October 26, Douda was killed. His death and the arrest of other civil society figures signal a systematic RSF campaign to hunt and eliminate Sudan’s human rights activists. Avaaz and rights groups warn this marks the strategic elimination of the 2019 revolution generation.

articles.title: Cancer, lung disease, miscarriages: are Uruguay’s rice workers paying too high a price to bring in the crop?
articles.trailText: The sector is a key driver of the Uruguayan economy, but widespread and ill-controlled use of agrochemicals is affecting employees’ health – despite official assurances
articles.summary: Uruguay’s booming rice sector, employing 30,000 across 500 farms, faces scrutiny as widespread use of agrochemicals like glyphosate, 2,4-D and chlorpyrifos correlates with cancer, lung disease and miscarriages in workers and nearby communities. Landmark case of Julio de los Santos, diagnosed with pesticide-induced illness, highlights insufficient buffer-zone enforcement, under-reporting of poisoning (938 complaints, one agrochemical claim, 2013-21) and lack of epidemiological studies. Researchers and unions warn of regulatory gaps, inadequate training and worker fear of reprisal. Despite bans on four high-risk pesticides since 2017, experts urge stronger monitoring, health protocols and transparent records.

articles.title: ‘They killed civilians in their beds’: chaos and brutality reign after fall of El Fasher
articles.trailText: Thousands have fled the Sudanese city in terror with stories of the Rapid Support Forces attacking and killing civilians
articles.summary: After an 18-month siege, RSF fighters overran El Fasher on 27 October, storming El Fasher South hospital and shooting wounded soldiers and civilians—including women—in their beds. The Joint Forces claim over 2,000 civilians have been killed since the city’s fall. Thousands fled on foot to Garney and Tawila, facing ambushes, ‘fake wells’, ransom demands of £6,000–£12,000 or detention, beatings and water mixed with flour. Survivors report severe injuries and mass graves. MSF in Tawila is treating over 1,000 malnourished, dehydrated arrivals, warning of a deepening humanitarian crisis.

articles.title: Donegal to Dakar: the Irish play about British rule hitting home in post-colonial Senegal
articles.trailText: An African staging of Brian Friel’s Translations resonates deeply as the country distances itself from France
articles.summary: On a humid evening in Dakar, Brrr Production staged Brian Friel’s Translations in French, fusing Irish jigs with Fula flute and African costumes to examine colonial power, language and identity. The 1833 tale of British officers renaming Donegal mirrors Senegal’s quest to decolonise—closing French bases, re-naming streets, challenging the CFA franc peg—and reclaim its Wolof heritage after years of Françafrique. Ahead of a schools and public tour, cast and audience draw parallels between Ireland and Senegal’s shared Atlantic post-colonial narratives of language, forced migration and lingering empire.

articles.title: Free medical cover has revolutionised healthcare in India. So why is it ailing?
articles.trailText: Modi’s Ayushman Bharat scheme put hospital treatment within reach of tens of millions of Indians for the first time. But the government’s unpaid bills may derail the reforms
articles.summary: Since its 2018 launch, Modi’s Ayushman Bharat scheme has issued 822m health IDs, covering up to ₹500,000 per family and enabling nearly 100m hospital admissions across public and private facilities. Yet unpaid claims exceeding ₹1 trn (₹4 bn in Kerala) and reimbursement delays of 4–6 months have sparked cash-flow crises for providers, prompting mass shutdowns in Haryana and deterring major hospital chains. Bureaucratic paperwork and fraud scrutiny exacerbate hold-ups. Observers warn that without prompt, inflation-adjusted payments, India’s largest social-health initiative risks collapse despite its life-changing impact for the poor.

articles.title: UK military equipment used by militia accused of genocide found in Sudan, UN told
articles.trailText: Exclusive: two dossiers of material seen by the security council raise questions over export of British arms to the UAE, which has been accused of supplying weapons to paramilitary RSF group
articles.summary: British-made small-arms training systems and engines for UAE-manufactured armoured personnel carriers have been recovered from RSF positions in Sudan, according to two dossiers seen by the UN Security Council. The RSF, accused of genocide, has used this British equipment, prompting scrutiny of UK arms exports to the UAE. Despite UN embargoes and previous allegations of UAE diversion to conflict zones, the UK issued further open licences for similar equipment in 2024. Critics cite treaty obligations against authorising exports with diversion risk and call for investigation into potential complicity in war crimes. The UAE denies supplying weapons to the RSF.

articles.title: Aid cuts in a Senegalese town risk taking away control from its ‘warrior’ women
articles.trailText: Being able to space out their babies is essential to the life and health chances of women in Joal. But now international aid cuts threaten to take away the few choices they have left
articles.summary: In Joal, Senegal, where women face back-to-back pregnancies, dwindling fish catches and extreme poverty, MSI Reproductive Choices’ UK-funded outreach offers IUDs and implants that let “warrior” women space births, improve health and work. Cuts to the Wish programme, slashed from £30m to £6.7m under past UK aid cuts—and threatened further—jeopardise this lifeline in a region with illegal abortions, power outages and under‐resourced clinics. Community “bajenu gox” door‐to‐door educators link 28,000 residents to services. Senegal’s govt targets modern contraception uptake but depends on partners as USAID and FCDO funds shrink.

articles.title: Brazil and Peru are failing uncontacted people – and the Amazon’s future is at stake | Julio Cusurichi Palacios and Beto Marubo
articles.trailText: As Cop30 approaches, a new report makes it clear the survival of isolated tribes is under threat as protections are eroded. It’s time our countries fulfilled their obligations to defend Indigenous people
articles.summary: NGO Survival International’s new report identifies 196 uncontacted tribes worldwide—over 60 in the Amazon, 90% in Brazil and Peru—half facing extinction within a decade from logging, mining, agribusiness, disease and criminal incursions. In Brazil, weakened Funai and the “marco temporal” law stall reserve demarcation. In Peru, bills 12215/2025-CR and 11822/2024-CR would cancel or shrink indigenous lands and allow oil drilling, blocking Yavari Mirim and Madre de Dios protections. Ahead of COP30, indigenous leaders urge both governments to reverse rollbacks and uphold climate and human rights commitments.

articles.title: Cholera is spreading fast, yet it can be stopped. Why haven’t we consigned it to history? | Hakainde Hichilema and Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus
articles.trailText: Vaccine production must be expanded to combat this ancient disease, especially in Africa, but a lack of political will is holding us back
articles.summary: Despite cholera being eliminated in high-income countries, over 6,800 deaths have occurred in 32 nations this year, driven by conflict, poverty and poor sanitation in Africa. The WHO-led Global Task Force on Cholera Control and its 2013 vaccine stockpile (255m doses delivered) rapidly deploy oral vaccines, but demand outstrips supply, forcing a single-dose regimen. Only one manufacturer currently produces at scale; Zambia’s 2024 pact with China’s Jijia aims to build local production. Experts stress that sustainable cholera control hinges on expanding vaccine output and, crucially, political commitment to safe water and sanitation.

articles.title: Secret mining studies and private deals: is a new gold rush quietly starting in El Salvador?
articles.trailText: As the country’s metal mining ban is lifted, rural communities fear a return of the contamination, violence and water shortages that cost so many lives and livelihoods in the past
articles.summary: Ten months after President Nayib Bukele repealed El Salvador’s 2009 metal-mining ban, environmentalists warn a secretive gold rush is under way. The government has classified mining studies as “trade secrets” even as private firms—Titan Resources, Nueva Esperanza, Agrícola San José—and Peruvian “consultants” position around the old El Dorado project. Infrastructure upgrades, armed forces at historic sites and new companies like Citalá Resources underscore fears of reactivation. NGOs face surveillance, politically charged trials and a 30% foreign-donations tax, while rural communities confront acute water scarcity (<1,800 m³ per capita) and arsenic risk. Opponents fear renewed contamination, violence and threats to cultural identity.

articles.title: UK’s biggest weapons firm BAE grounds ‘lifeline’ aircraft delivering food aid
articles.trailText: Exclusive: In the year they announced record profits, Britain’s arms maker has revoked licence to fly for planes taking supplies of food to starving people in South Sudan, Somalia and DRC
articles.summary: BAE Systems, buoyed by £3 bn record profits tied to the Israel–Gaza and Ukraine wars, has voluntarily surrendered the UK CAA type certificate for its Advanced Turbo-Prop (ATP) fleet, grounding EnComm Aviation’s 12 aid aircraft. Between March 2023 and September 2025 these planes delivered 18,677 tonnes of food to South Sudan, Somalia, DRC, Tanzania, CAR and Chad under WFP and DRC contracts now cancelled. EnComm has launched a £187 m negligence suit, as BAE shifts focus to NATO’s 5% defence-spend boost, cutting off a critical lifeline to millions in crisis.

articles.title: Plain rice and little else: life for 120,000 refugees inside Mauritania’s vast camp on Mali’s border
articles.trailText: Over a quarter of a million refugees live in Mbera and nearby villages, and more than half are under 18. But aid cuts mean providing essentials has become even harder
articles.summary: In Mauritania’s Mbera camp on the Mali border some 120,000 refugees rely on dwindling aid after this year’s funding cuts forced WFP to halve monthly food or cash support from 90,000 to 53,000 people and suspend child-nutrition programmes. Over half of the camp’s residents are under 18; many have never seen Mali. Despite schools, a market, bank and biometric registration, families survive on nearly plain rice. Local volunteers run basic healthcare, crop and firefighting initiatives, while leaders like 84-year-old Mohamed Ag Malha maintain routines and hope for return.

articles.title: ‘They told me not to speak out’: the woman who took on China – and won her husband’s freedom
articles.trailText: After fleeing Chinese repression, Uyghurs Idris and Zeynure Hasan thought their family would be safe. But Beijing’s growing influence led to Idris’s arrest and a long battle to be reunited
articles.summary: After fleeing Xinjiang’s crackdown to Istanbul in 2011, Uyghur activists Zeynure Hasan and her husband Idris built careers teaching and translating until China pressured Interpol to issue a red notice. Idris’s July 2021 arrest in Morocco triggered Zeynure’s global campaign—social media updates, Moroccan embassy protests and appeals by human rights NGOs secured Interpol’s notice cancellation and a UN review. Diplomatic pressure from Beijing stalled courts until US secretary of state Marco Rubio quietly brokered Idris’s extraction to Washington in February 2025. By September, Zeynure and their three children obtained Canadian visas, reuniting the family in Toronto.

articles.title: Africa’s children: 20 years on, what happened to the millennium babies?
articles.trailText: In 2005, the Guardian documented the births of 10 babies as a way to tell the story of millions across the continent. We caught up with three of them, finding hardship – and hope
articles.summary: In 2005 the Guardian recorded ten African "millennium babies" to chart progress towards the UN's MDGs; two decades later, three were found in Malawi, Ghana and South Africa, illustrating uneven development. In Malawi, 20-year-old Innocent Smoke works in road-construction testing soil while rent-paying with limited utilities, married with a newborn, and fears job insecurity amid youth unemployment. In Ghana, 19-year-old Hannah Klutsey, with chronic health issues and early school exit, survives as a cake-baking apprentice under crowded conditions. In South Africa, 20-year-old Angel Siyavuya Swartbooi, fresh from rehab, aspires to electrician training from his family's cramped rental, highlighting stalled poverty and job outcomes.

articles.title: Fair Work Agency requires proper resources | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Ruth Wilkinson says the workers’ rights watchdog will only succeed with sustained investment and political will
articles.summary: Ruth Wilkinson welcomes Matthew Taylor’s appointment to chair the new Fair Work Agency but warns the single enforcement body will fall short without sustained investment and political will. Chronic underresourcing of HMRC’s national minimum wage unit and the Employment Agency Standards Inspectorate has undermined inspections, investigations and prosecutions, disproportionately impacting insecure and ethnic minority workers. Wilkinson urges national and sectoral strategies to eliminate insecure work, forced labour, modern slavery and child labour, and calls for a long-term employment, financial and human resources plan to ensure the agency can deliver meaningful change.

articles.title: Thailand to let Myanmar refugees work to counter aid cuts and labour shortages
articles.trailText: The move, welcomed by UN, will allow thousands of people living in camps to support themselves and their families
articles.summary: Thailand will allow up to 42,600 Myanmar refugees in nine border camps to obtain work permits, aiming to offset US aid cuts and plug labour gaps after Cambodian workers left. An August labour ministry resolution mandates health screenings and employer vetting, granting refugees formal jobs, access to banking and the ability to support families. UNHCR and aid groups hail the move as a regional precedent that could boost local GDP and foster self-reliance, though language barriers and social integration challenges persist. Agencies will track economic impact and seek to extend rights to urban refugees.

articles.title: Anti-malaria funding cuts could lead to ‘deadliest resurgence ever’, study warns
articles.trailText: Expected reduction in contributions by wealthy countries likely to cost millions of lives and billions in lost growth
articles.summary: Study warns that 20% cuts to Global Fund malaria financing could cause 33 million extra cases, 82 000 deaths and $5.1 billion GDP loss in sub-Saharan Africa by 2030. A full collapse may trigger 525 million new cases, 990 000 deaths (750 000 children) and $83 billion lost GDP. Conversely, the Fund’s $18 billion ask would avert 865 million cases, 1.86 million deaths and yield a $230 billion GDP boost. Extreme weather, crises and rising insecticide/drug resistance heighten the threat. African leaders, Malaria No More UK and philanthropists like Dangote urge G7, private sector and high-net-worth donors to close the funding gap.

articles.title: AI-generated ‘poverty porn’ fake images being used by aid agencies
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Pictures depicting the most vulnerable and poorest people are being used in social media campaigns in the sector, driven by concerns over consent and cost
articles.summary: Researchers and charity workers warn that stock photo sites are flooded with AI-generated images depicting extreme poverty—children in mud, cracked earth, sexual violence survivors—to fuel social media campaigns by major NGOs. Dubbed “poverty porn 2.0” by Arsenii Alenichev of Antwerp’s Institute of Tropical Medicine, these synthetic scenes cost less and bypass consent, but entrench harmful tropes. Adobe Stock and Freepik host dozens of hyperrealist, racialized images under queries like “poverty,” while platforms struggle to police bias. Some charities, like Plan International and the UN, have since withdrawn AI-driven campaigns amid ethical backlash over consent, dignity and the risk of amplifying prejudice.

articles.title: UNAids is set to close in 2026 – four years early. Are experts right to be alarmed?
articles.trailText: The move to shut the agency comes as aid budgets are being slashed, leading to fears that global progress on HIV may be reversed
articles.summary: UN secretary-general proposes sunsetting UNAids by end-2026 amid UN80 cost cuts (halving its 600 staff) and shrinking foreign aid, alarming experts who warn this could reverse recent gains in HIV control. In eastern Europe and central Asia, new infections are up 48% and deaths 32%, with marginalized groups losing vital advocacy and antiretroviral access. UNAids provides unique data on epidemics—67% of 40.8m people with HIV live in Africa—and coordinates funding shifts from donors to domestic budgets. Closure threatens monitoring, targeted prevention (e.g., mother-to-child) and rollout of innovations like lenacapavir, risking resurgence.

articles.title: ‘The loss of education is the loss of the future itself’: Gaza’s children and teachers on two years without school
articles.trailText: With 97% of schools destroyed or damaged, 600,000 children have just begun their third year out of formal education. Three students and a teacher share their stories – and their hopes
articles.summary: After two years of war, 97% of Gaza’s schools lie damaged, leaving 600,000 children without formal education. 12-year-old Juwayriya recalls her bombed classroom and dreams of journalism; teacher Naglaa struggles to keep lessons alive in shelters and online; nine-year-old Sarah mourns lost classmates and her thwarted medical ambitions; seven-year-old Ismail, now in Egypt, faces disrupted learning but clings to hope at an informal refugee school. Amid rubble and displacement, education emerges as an act of defiance and the only path to a future.

articles.title: US anti-vax stance to blame for continent-wide surge in measles, say experts
articles.trailText: The disease was eliminated across the Americas in 2024, but urgent vaccination drives are now under way as cases rise from Mexico to Bolivia after outbreaks farther north
articles.summary: Governments across Latin America are racing to curb a 34-fold rise in measles this year—driven by US outbreaks after anti-vax policies under RFK Jr.—which has ended the Americas’ measles-free status. Pan-American Health Organization reports 11,668 cases across 10 countries, over half in the US and Canada (five deaths), with Mexico hit hardest (4,800 cases, 22 deaths) and Bolivia next (354). Brazil has launched nationwide MMR campaigns, ring vaccination and door-to-door drives; Mexico, Bolivia and others target unvaccinated communities, including Mennonite settlements. MMR coverage stands at 86%, below the 95% herd-immunity threshold, with US misinformation hampering uptake.

articles.title: At 12 an Israeli missile ‘ripped off’ her face. Now Mazyouna is safe in the US – but not all the scars have healed
articles.trailText: The young teenager’s treatment is a rare story of hope from the two-year war in Gaza. With the ceasefire now in effect, she hopes to see her father again
articles.summary: Mazyouna Damoo, 13, lost half her face and two siblings died when an Israeli missile struck her Gaza home in June 2024. After repeated permit rejections, international media coverage secured her evacuation to El Paso, Texas, for multi-stage reconstructive surgery at the children’s hospital. Over a year she’s had cheek, lip and jaw reconstructions, now eats, speaks and attends school, learning English and Spanish. She dreams of becoming a doctor. Her mother preserves Palestinian heritage, while her father remains in Gaza, separated by US visa limits, and her wartime trauma persists.

articles.title: Nursing unions call for UK to back prosecutions for war crimes against health workers
articles.trailText: Calls come as report shows number of health workers killed in conflicts has risen five-fold in less than a decade
articles.summary: Senior nursing and medical bodies, including the RCN and BMA, urge the UK to fully back ICC prosecutions for war crimes targeting health workers after a five-fold rise in conflict-related deaths—from 175 in 2016 to 932 in 2024—according to new RCN data drawing on Insecurity Insights. Attacks and arrests of medical staff in Palestine, Ukraine, Lebanon and Myanmar underscore mounting threats. RCN chief Nicola Ranger and BMA’s Andrew Green demand stronger enforcement of international law and restoration of UK aid to 0.7% of GDP. Testimonies from Afghanistan, Gaza and Myanmar highlight intimidation, resource shortages and impunity-induced trauma.

articles.title: Thousands trapped in El Fasher siege on ‘edge of survival’, says report
articles.trailText: The city – the Sudanese army’s last stronghold in the west of the country – has withstood more than 500 days of attacks by paramilitary RSF
articles.summary: A MedGlobal survey of 900 recent evacuees reveals that after 549 days of RSF encirclement, El Fasher’s 250,000 residents face utter desolation: 90% of homes destroyed or looted, chronic food and water shortages, acute malnutrition in 27.5% of infants and 60% of adolescent girls, and three-quarters displaced multiple times. Indiscriminate RSF artillery and drone strikes on homes, hospitals and shelters—killing dozens—have made the city uninhabitable. The RSF’s raised embankments now fully encircle the city, thwarting escapes and aid deliveries. Communications blackouts block aid; airdrops by Sudan’s army barely suffice. UN and rights bodies decry genocide risks.

articles.title: ‘This generation is defiant’: Gen Z protests set to resume in Morocco despite deaths and arrests
articles.trailText: Activists call for fresh demonstrations this weekend with three people killed and more than 500 reportedly arrested since unrest started in late September
articles.summary: Since late September Morocco’s GenZ212 youth-led protests over underfunded healthcare and education versus World Cup spending have left three reported dead—including 24-year-old filmmaker Abdessamade—and more than 500 arrested. Organizers, mobilizing on Discord (200,000+ subscribers), demand a transparent investigation into his killing. Lawyers say 272 remain detained, including 36 minors, facing unlawful assembly charges that carry up to 10-year sentences. High-profile arrests include rapper Hamza Raid (#FreeKoulchi). Human rights groups call for detainee release; King Mohammed VI pledged rapid reforms but ignored corruption demands. PM Aziz Akhannouch says the government is ready for dialogue. New protests are planned for 18 October.

articles.title: Can Colombia embrace clean energy without damaging the Amazon?
articles.trailText: At the foot of the Andes, a Canadian firm has plans for one of the country’s biggest copper mines, but many say the carbon-rich forests and clean rivers are too high a price to pay
articles.summary: Copper Giant Resources plans to explore some 136,000 ha near Mocoa for up to 2 m tonnes of copper and molybdenum—metals critical for batteries and turbines—but locals, fearing water pollution, ecosystem loss and páramo damage, have blockaded roads and set up a resistance camp. In June, CorpoAmazonia designated 93,000 ha, including parts of the concessions, as an “area of ecological importance,” restricting mining. The dispute highlights tension between President Petro’s drive to secure strategic energy-transition minerals and his promise to safeguard the Colombian Amazon’s biodiversity and carbon-sink function.

articles.title: ‘The universe has opened up for us’: meet the astro-ambassadors who welcome stargazers to the Himalayas
articles.trailText: A tourism initiative in India’s first dark sky reserve has brought new hope to a community as employment means they can stay close to their roots and culture
articles.summary: In Hanle, Ladakh’s new dark sky reserve, 25 locals (18 women) trained as “astro-ambassadors” guide tourists through stargazing, boosting homestay tourism and reviving the community. Controlled lights protect the Indian Astronomical Observatory’s research; villagers earn up to tenfold city salaries and reconnect with Buddhist and pastoral star lore. Annual star parties attract enthusiasts nationwide. Initiatives blend livelihood, heritage and science, but rising tourist vehicles and military camp lighting threaten Hanle’s pristine “Bortle 1” skies, prompting ambassadors to brief commanders on curbing light pollution to safeguard this high-altitude astronomy hub.

articles.title: High youth death rates are an ‘emerging crisis’, global health study warns
articles.trailText: Alcohol, suicide and injuries driving rises among teenagers and young adults despite overall rates falling, authors say
articles.summary: The 2025 Global Burden of Disease study in Lancet, compiling 300,000 sources and 16,500 researchers, warns of an ‘emerging crisis’: rising death rates among 10–29 year-olds. In North and Latin America spikes stem from drugs, alcohol and suicide tied to surging anxiety and depression; in sub-Saharan Africa excess youth mortality is driven by infectious diseases, injuries and maternal causes. Overall life expectancy rebounded post-COVID to 76.3 years for women, yet chronic diseases now account for two-thirds of ill health and half of all disease is preventable, prompting calls for youth-centered, integrated health investments.

articles.title: Gaza PhD student ‘heartbroken’ as family blocked from entering the UK
articles.trailText: Manar al-Houbi’s husband and children refused entry despite her winning a scholarship to cover tuition fees, living costs and housing for them all
articles.summary: Gaza PhD candidate Manar al-Houbi secured a fully funded Cara scholarship at the University of Glasgow covering tuition, housing and living costs for her and her dependants. Despite visa rules allowing full-time PhD students to bring family, the UK FCDO refused entry for her husband and children, citing UK immigration policy, while Deputy PM David Lammy blamed Israeli exit permissions—denied by Israel’s COGAT. Displaced in a Khan Younis tent after their Rafah home was bombed, al-Houbi plans research on media’s role in combating violence against women and hopes to teach in Gaza post-PhD. Cara and Scottish ministers are pressing the UK government to secure her family’s evacuation immediately.

articles.title: Torture, blackmail, extortion: the dangers of queer online dating in Ghana
articles.trailText: Homophobic attacks on LGBTQ+ community rising as criminals, using social media to lure victims, are emboldened by political debate
articles.summary: Criminal gangs in Ghana exploit dating apps like Grindr, TikTok and Facebook to lure gay men, bisexual men and transgender women into isolated locations for assault, blackmail and extortion. Often armed with footage of torture—such as trans chef Delali’s three-hour beating or the viral ‘Kofi’ attack—they threaten to expose victims under a climate of heightened homophobia stoked by an anti-gay bill debated in parliament and election campaigns. Rightify Ghana documents a threefold rise in reported abuses in 2024, but many incidents remain unreported amid police indifference. Viral videos and AI filters fuel further violence, experts warn.

articles.title: US ‘undermining global health’ by threatening to strip funding from aid projects that do not fit its political agenda
articles.trailText: Trump administration reported to be planning expansion of ‘global gag rule’ to halt any initiatives promoting diversity, equity and inclusion
articles.summary: Trump administration plans to extend its ‘global gag rule’ (Mexico City policy) to bar or punish any foreign governments, NGOs and multilateral organisations promoting abortion, “gender ideology” or diversity, equity and inclusion (DEI), threatening to cut all US funding. For the first time, UN agencies and foreign governments face “hard choices” between DEI programmes—such as HIV prevention among young women and gender-sensitive health services—and critical aid. Experts warn the expansion infringes sovereignty, risks clinic closures, increased deaths, violence and destabilises decades of health partnerships. Campaigners urge governments to reject conditional US aid to preserve human rights and public health.

articles.title: ‘I have searched and searched for help’: the Sudanese women left alone to live hand to mouth in Chad’s desert camps
articles.trailText: As the war in Sudan pushes more people across the border, malnutrition is on the rise in Chad’s remote settlements where 86% of the refugees are women and children
articles.summary: Since 2023, 878,000 Sudanese refugees—86% women and children—have streamed into remote desert camps in eastern Chad, where scarce water (≈9 L/day), minimal rations and no work have driven rising malnutrition and maternal emergencies. With a single MSF hospital in Metche and one ambulance for tens of thousands, women reach care dangerously late—fueling ruptured uteri and fatalities—and malnutrition wards swell. Slashed international aid (only 69% of UN appeals met) threatens further cuts to food and education.

articles.title: Fast-fashion recycling: how ‘the castoff capital of the world’ is making Indian factory workers sick
articles.trailText: Reports of lung disease, skin conditions and even cancer are rising in Panipat, which recycles 1 million tonnes of textile waste a year
articles.summary: Panipat’s 20,000 recycling mills process around 1 million tonnes of discarded garments a year, shredding global fast-fashion waste into ‘shoddy’ yarn. Thousands of poorly ventilated workstations expose at least 300,000 laborers to airborne lint and microplastics, fueling chronic coughs, COPD, skin conditions and cancer risks. With minimal safety gear and no childcare, workers like Neerma Devi face irreversible lung damage across generations. Simultaneously, 600+ legal and illegal bleaching and dyeing units dump toxic effluents into local drains and groundwater, sparking widespread skin ailments and non-communicable diseases amid weak enforcement.

articles.title: This Patagonian village has glacier-fed rivers and majestic scenery. The only problem? Sewage
articles.trailText: El Chaltén is a paradise for hikers. But the seasonal influx of tourists stretches the sanitation infrastructure to breaking point – and even a legal victory has not provided a solution
articles.summary: In Argentina’s El Chaltén, a surge of up to 10,000 daily hikers overwhelms sewage plants, sending untreated waste and antibiotic-resistant E. coli into glacier-fed Fitz Roy and Las Vueltas rivers. After a 2023 court victory under the Escazú treaty, authorities pledged to upgrade treatment by January 2025, yet pollution persists. Community group Guardians of El Chaltén Basin and biologists documented multiresistant bacteria near plant outfalls, prompting new lawsuits and oversight committees. Locals demand robust enforcement, infrastructure expansion and sustained water quality monitoring in this Unesco heritage park.

articles.title: Seeing double: the wooden carvings that celebrate the Yorùbá’s unique connection to twins
articles.trailText: The Ìbejì Project is resurrecting interest in the traditional art of the Yorùbá people, who have one of the highest rates of twin births in the world
articles.summary: After acquiring a pair of traditional Yorùbá twin statuettes (ère ìbejì) in 2022, Nigerian curator Kayode Adegbola launched the Ìbejì Project in 2023 to revive the spiritual art form tied to the region’s high twin birth rate. Historically, Yorùbá families carved and cared for ère ìbejì to honor twins’ spirits, but museum collections scattered originals abroad. Adegbola collects, exhibits and pairs them with contemporary artists exploring duality, absence and continuity. His advocacy has reignited local interest, prompted new acquisitions and plans for a scholarly book, aiming to reposition ère ìbejì as a living, global cultural heritage.

articles.title: Trouble brewing: Maya people in Yucatán fear new Heineken plant’s thirst for water
articles.trailText: Indigenous groups in Mexico opposed to the planned brewery say families already have little access to water – and that their way of life is also under threat
articles.summary: Indigenous Maya in Yucatán are mobilizing against Heineken’s new $2.75bn brewery in Kanasín, warning its annual 400m-litre output may deplete the sacred Cenote Ring aquifer, already strained after water availability halved since 2003 and 121,000 locals lacked potable water in 2020. Heineken promises 2 litres of water per litre of beer and 2,500 jobs, but activists contest these claims, noting past contamination from pig farms and a Modelo brewery, that only 3% of state wastewater is treated, fear untreated effluent pollution, highlight lack of ‘free, prior and informed consent’, and warn of cultural erosion, gentrification and rights violations.

articles.title: ‘We called ourselves the lifeboat crew’: how fired USAID workers launched a rescue project ‘to save as many babies as we can’
articles.trailText: After the Trump administration closed the organisation down, a group of former staff secured new funding for almost 80 programmes, benefiting an estimated 40 million people
articles.summary: After the Trump administration shuttered USAID and forced mass layoffs, former agency staff formed the Project Resource Optimization (Pro) “lifeboat crew” to salvage vital overseas aid. By vetting cancelled programmes for cost-effective, life-saving impact, they matched 79 projects across more than 30 countries with $110m in new funding from anonymous philanthropies and individuals—benefiting 40m people, many under five. After an initial anchor grant, they expanded outreach to multiple donors. Operating under the Center for Global Development, Pro aims to “buy time” for NGOs, not replace long-term solutions. Three projects regained USAID support; nine could not be saved. Example: Alima’s malnutrition, maternity and vaccination services in Mali.

articles.title: The families of Syria’s disappeared are asking for the truth. Our country cannot rebuild until we have it | Wafa Mustafa
articles.trailText: Over 160,000 people, including my father, were abducted by the Assad regime. The country’s new commission for the missing must be inclusive and independent to restore our trust
articles.summary: Wafa Mustafa recounts her 11-year ordeal after her father, Ali Mustafa, was abducted by Assad’s forces in July 2013—one among 160,000+ documented enforced disappearances. Trapped in “ambiguous loss,” families lack bodies, records or closure. After the regime’s December 2024 collapse opened prisons, survivors still found no trace. Mustafa calls on Syria’s interim government to end disappearances and sectarian violence, and to establish an inclusive, independent National Commission for the Missing—family-led to guarantee truth, justice and rebuild trust. She stresses Syrians, not foreign powers, must sustain this fight until every loved one’s fate is known.

articles.title: Crowded camps, stagnant water and not enough doctors: first the floods, now disease stalks millions in Pakistan
articles.trailText: As the waters recede, a surge in cases of cholera, diarrhoea, malaria and dengue has compounded the misery of people who have already seen their homes and crops disappear
articles.summary: UN estimates floods since June in Pakistan’s Punjab have affected over 6M and killed nearly 1,000 (250 children), displacing 2.5M and damaging 15% of homes in Multan (5M pop, 3,720 sq km). Flood camps lack sanitation, clean water and medical staff; government reports 56,415 camp beds with six fixed clinics and 28 mobile units, yet many have seen no doctor. Local hospitals report doubling of cholera, malaria, dengue and diarrhoea. WHO notes an 87% surge in vector-borne diseases (June–Aug). Women and children face inadequate latrines, no menstrual supplies and security risks, worsening post-flood health crises.

articles.title: Women behind the lens: ‘I thought, who is this woman? I need to know her’
articles.trailText: Indian artist Indu Antony was mesmerised when she first saw 78-year-old Cecilia and has put her at the heart of a project that interrogates women’s safety in public spaces and celebrates friendship
articles.summary: Indian artist Indu Antony’s Cecilia’ed project centers 78-year-old Cecilia—a vibrant figure defying age and gender norms—as a ‘celebrity’ in public-space interventions across Bengaluru, India’s third most dangerous city for women. Antony documented Cecilia in 100 intimate photos, then used police data to pinpoint unsafe streets, staging ribbon-cuttings, distributing Cecilia-branded matchboxes and running neighbourhood workshops and male-space screenings. Cecilia’ed fuses feminist geography with playful activism, reclaiming urban spaces, shifting power dynamics and celebrating female friendship, resilience and visibility through community-led art.

articles.title: ‘Will my baby be born in a tent? Will it have food?’: what it’s like to be pregnant in Gaza
articles.trailText: The World Health Organization has warned that more than 40% of pregnant women in the Gaza Strip are malnourished. Here, Nour Ziad al-Batsh, who is expecting her third child in March, describes her daily struggle to find food and healthcare
articles.summary: Nour Ziad al-Batsh, expecting her third child in Gaza, describes life under siege: 40% of pregnant women are malnourished, and extreme fatigue has triggered bleeding, dizziness and tremors. Doctors Without Borders classed her high-risk, yet hospitals lack capacity for her critical need. Displacement and relentless bombings destroyed her home and her husband’s optical practice; she now lives with two malnourished children in a tent near Nuseirat without water, power or steady food. Sky-rocketing prices, 50% bank-exchange fees and imminent hunger fuel her fear over finding basic care and nourishment for her baby.

articles.title: As US warships prowl the Caribbean, our region must hold fast against Trump’s gaslighting
articles.trailText: American attacks have killed more than 14 people they claim were drug traffickers in our waters. Now our islands are at risk of being dragged into a manufactured conflict we are ill-equipped to endure
articles.summary: US warships have launched missile strikes on alleged drug boats off Venezuela, killing over 14 people, while Trinidad and Tobago granted access without Caricom approval. Washington casts the Caribbean as a narco-transit hub to obscure US drug demand and secure oil interests, endangering fishers, tourism and fragile economies. Venezuela has mobilized its navy and regional solidarity is fraying under Trump’s election-driven spectacle. Caribbean leaders call for diplomacy, evidence-based operations and unity to prevent small states from becoming collateral damage.

articles.title: ‘She didn’t realise how dangerous it was’: London-bound student held in China over Tibet support
articles.trailText: Zhang Yadi was due to begin a degree in the UK but the activist vanished on holiday amid tensions over Dalai Lama
articles.summary: Zhang Yadi, 22, a Chinese Buddhist student and Tibetan rights activist who wrote for the pro-Tibet newsletter Chinese Youth Stand For Tibet, vanished in late July while touring Tibetan areas of Sichuan. She had been due to start an anthropology graduate degree at SOAS, London. Beijing now holds her in Changsha on “inciting separatism” charges—punishable by up to 15 years—under a new law targeting overseas ethnic “disunity.” Friends, family and human rights groups allege her activism abroad and the Dalai Lama’s defiance prompted her detention, and there has been no contact since her arrest.

articles.title: ‘It’s more than martial arts – we teach courage’: the Afghan sisters honing karate skills in Iran
articles.trailText: The three women live in exile where, despite an increase in deportations and rising hostility towards migrants, they use sport to empower women
articles.summary: Shokoufeh Jafari (29) and her sisters Maryam (23) and Mandana (20) fled Afghanistan in 1998 and now train Kyokushin karate in exile in Shiraz, Iran. Encouraged by their former military officer father, they rose to represent Afghanistan internationally, winning medals at the 2019 Asian Kyokushin Championship. After the Taliban banned women’s sports, they opened a dojo for Afghan girls, teaching martial arts and self-belief amid intensified deportations (800,000 Afghans expelled June–July 2025) and hostility in Iran. Lacking citizenship and facing prejudice, they preserve Afghan culture at home while pursuing law, genetic research and robotics, and advocating women’s rights.

articles.title: How the world’s taste for soya is eating Brazil’s Amazon
articles.trailText: Cultivation of the crop has made a few wealthy but at a huge cost to untouched forest as it spreads across vast areas of former wilderness
articles.summary: In Brazil’s Amazon, soya cultivation has surged across nine states, driven by global demand—particularly China’s feed market—making Brazil the top exporter with 51.5m tonnes in early 2025. While agribusiness bolsters GDP and rural jobs, expansion breaches deforestation moratoria, fuels legal battles, threatens biodiversity and indigenous lands, and clogs highways like BR-364. EU deforestation-free import rules and a 2006 soya moratorium curbed some clearing, but post-2008 forest loss and secondary road sprawl continue. Pioneering crop science and tax incentives sustain growth, but experts warn unchecked soya fronts imperil climate stability, watersheds and vulnerable communities.

articles.title: ‘I feel broken’: hardship bites for thousands of South Sudanese stranded and unable to get home
articles.trailText: Renk, an onward travel hub for people fleeing war in Sudan, has become a bottleneck as aid cuts leave displaced families exposed and in need
articles.summary: Since April 2023, over 800,000 South Sudanese have fled Sudan’s war to Renk, a transit hub on the White Nile, where IOM’s relocation programme moved 250,000 people until June 2025. Funding cuts tied to a US aid freeze forced suspension of the scheme, leaving 9,000+ returnees stranded in overcrowded camps with scarce food, water and shelter. Families like 66-year-old Musa Rajab have spent their cash grants on tarpaulins or sold possessions for essentials. The IOM and gov’t urge swift international support; recent UK funds moved 915 people but capacity remains overstretched.

articles.title: ‘A donkey cart out of El Fasher costs more than a new car’: how 500 days under siege is tearing the city apart
articles.trailText: North Darfur’s capital has been under siege for 500 days, its people facing starvation, blockade and bombardment, with scant hope of relief, says Sudanese political scientist Sarra Majdoub
articles.summary: El Fasher, North Darfur’s capital, has endured a 500-day siege by the RSF since May 2024. Trenches crisscross flooded streets as civilians shelter from daily dawn-to-dusk shelling. Drones patrol the skies, intensifying fear. RSF fortifications block all but one exit—a perilous, extortionate trek to Tawila, where a donkey cart costs more than a car. Starvation looms: millet fetches $100 for 2 kg, communal kitchens offer one meagre meal, volunteers treat shrapnel wounds with scant supplies. With no aid and external military support bolstering the RSF, El Fasher’s survival hangs by a thread.

articles.title: US refuses to back UN declaration on noncommunicable diseases
articles.trailText: General assembly backs new targets on cancer, diabetes and heart disease but Robert F Kennedy Jr objects
articles.summary: At the UN General Assembly, US health secretary Robert F.
